channel.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
channel.description:
## Document, Share, Discuss ##
Hello remote hive builders!
Congratulations on building an Open Source Beehive - we'd love to see your hive and hear about your experiences fabricating, assembling and installing bees! Please share any media below - you can upload or link it anywhere in your response (this forum is pretty functional).
We look forward to seeing your work!

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@marcob8890 Mark Benson)

This is what it's all about. 1 CTB and 1 Warre in the Dallas area, both doing great.

Dallas 3.jpg1113x835 105 KB

Read full topic

item.description:
Malcolm Nealon wrote:

Here's mine.

Now I just need to populate the thing.

Looks wrong, because the entrance is facing south, which I understand is the best direction.

The area immediately south and west of the hive will be populated with bee friendly flowers.

Mal

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@mark_kidwell mark kidwell)
item.description:
mark kidwell wrote:

Wanted to share my hive pictures but as my old account wouldn't allow me to log on I had to create a new account with limited priviledges. I have had bees in my hive for nearing 8 weeks. They have built comb to the 15th bar so I built a second story to provide more space. I also had my micro usb break on my smart citizen baseboard and tried to get Acrobatics to sell me the base only but they said to contact opensourcebeehives for support? If someone can help me please email mark_kidwell@msn.com

Read full topic

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@marcob8890 Mark Benson)
item.description:
Mark Benson wrote:

We managed to get all 7 hives installed and populated on Friday. I was a long day but everything went as planned and hopefully we got them all off to a good start.

P5010065.JPG2560x1920 1.1 MB
P5010080.JPG2560x1920 1.14 MB
P5010069.JPG2560x1920 1.13 MB

Read full topic

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@marcob8890 Mark Benson)
item.description:
Mark Benson wrote:

I built these feeders to fit into the Warre based on my friend Ed's recommendation. It should hold a gallon of feed and hopefully get them off to a good start. We pick up the bees on Friday and will start a total of 7 hives in S.E. Texas. Another is being started by Nils & Miriana in Dallas, and they have 3 other people wanting to start hives. I built a total of 10 hives on speculation, they are all gone and I need to build more. Although the aesthetics may not be important to the health of the colony it has been a big part of people accepting these hives, good engineering is as much art as it is engineering and you guys did a great job on designing these hives.

IMG_0652.JPG640x640 111 KB
IMG_0651.JPG640x640 133 KB
IMG_0653.JPG640x640 152 KB

Read full topic

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@mrtorrence Cody Harrison)
item.description:
Cody Harrison wrote:

Won't let me upload because I'm a "new" user but hopefully these links will work:

Final product
Full album

I used a CARB phase II compliant Birch that seemed to work pretty well. Not sure if it was exterior or interior, or what the grade was. If anyone can tell from looking at the label halfway through the album I'd be interested to know. I also coated it in linseed oil (how many coats did others use??) and sealed the roof with beeswax.

This hive will hopefully be installed at the Cincinnati zoo in the coming weeks.

Read full topic

item.author: no-reply@example.com (@hardcherry Alison white)
item.description:
Alison white wrote:

I convinced a friend with a CNC to build me a hive.
They are so popular, we decided to put up a website.
I'll be picking up my TBH on the 18th, and transferring my bees into it shortly after.
I am looking forward to building with my RPi 2 for monitoring and just plain geekiness.

I've been a beekeeper for about 5+ years.

http://connectedhive.com

Ali White
Austin, Texas

Read full topic

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@marcob8890 Mark Benson)
item.description:
Mark Benson wrote:

Here's the finished product. I took the nested file and scaled it in Rhino to 1/6 scale. I then exported as a .dxf and imported into Corel Draw (Epilog Lasers uses Corel as it's post processor). I used a laser friendly plywood from Laser Bits, Birch plywood requires so much power that the wood gets fried in the process! I had to sand a bit to get the fit right but all together it only took about an hour to make it. I used a Dremel with a router attachment to rout the dados and then I assembled it without glue just like the full size version. I will probably end up gluing some parts because it will be handled so much.
I hope nobody minds the plug for this website.
This will make a great tool for explaining how a hive works and I will be modeling the Warre to show the differences between designs.

1_6 Scale Ply 6.jpg480x640 80.5 KB
1_6 Scale Ply 2.jpg480x640 91.2 KB

Read full topic

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@marcob8890 Mark Benson)
item.description:
Mark Benson wrote:

CTB Model 1_10 Scale.jpg1224x1632 678 KB
I thought it would be nice to have some models to take to events where full size hives would be out of place. I did this one at 1/10th scale on a 3d printer. The top is removable and the internal parts installed. It's probably too small and fragile for a lot of handling. My next step will be to scale it to 1/8" plywood and cut it on a laser.

Read full topic

item.title: Share OSBeehive Photos Here!
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@marcob8890 Mark Benson)
item.description:
Mark Benson wrote:

I used 3/4" marine plywood that was close to 19mm thick. I had some problems with 1/4" shank bits. I like to use 1/4" cutters to reduce the sawdust. I tried using a 1/4" cutter with a 1/4" shank and broke or shook loose 4 of them. The only way I could keep one running was to reduce my cut speed to 30ipm. I am now using a 1/4" cutter with a 1/2" shank made by Whiteside (p/n 1058) with great success. I organize the cuts by part , group several parts, and make gcode files for each group. It takes a little longer this way but it allows me to make adjustments if needed. When I get comfortable with the individual files I'll run the whole sheet in one file. My default cut speed is 60ipm with a 3 1/2hp, 22,000rpm router. I am testing the upper limit as I go and I think I'll be able to settle around 90ipm.
The CTB takes me about 1 1/2 hours and eventually I hope to get that down to under an hour. The Warre is between 2-3 hours with a goal of under 2 hours. Both cut times include time to change files. The designs are both well engineered and complete. I've run 6 so far and I'm still awestruck at how well thought out they are. The only change I made was to add rabbits for the acrylic windows on the Warre.
I use a Makita 3/8" mini belt sander for cleanup(what little is needed). It's small enough to get into the mortise cuts and eats up end grain.

I hope this helps, please feel free to contact me if you need any help.

Good luck with your first cut!

About my machine:
I built my machine from a kit sold by www.cncrouterparts.com. It has nema 34 motors and a rack and pinion system, heavy duty for a kit machine. It cost me about $7k to get a functional 9' x 5' machine that I'm happy with. It's a good way to go if you can afford the sweat equity. It was a fair amount of work and if I was to do it again I would buy the prewired electronics box.

Read full topic
